forecast.no_outcome_scenario: By July 1, all hitters on ESPN’s stats leaderboard are below .400 (typical leader in the .360–.395 range), so no player is listed at .400+ on the page used for resolution.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: A hitter maintains an exceptional early-season run and sits at .400+ on July 1 (e.g., a high-contact, high-BABIP profile à la Arraez/Kwan), or the resolving ESPN page includes non-qualified players and at least one part-time player with limited PAs remains at or above .400.
forecast.rationale: Baseline: Having a qualified hitter at .400 on July 1 is historically very rare in the modern era. Even remarkable starts (e.g., 2008 Chipper Jones, 2023 Luis Arraez) typically regress below .400 by late June. By mid-to-late May, the sample sizes are growing, and variance declines; sustaining .400 into July would require continued elite performance and luck. Status quo therefore favors No. Evidence: Recent seasons show few, if any, instances of a qualified hitter still at .400 on July 1. Nothing structural (rules, ball, run environment) in 2025 suggests a step-change that would materially increase this probability. The background article about Judge’s .400 start underscores early-season noise rather than July sustainability. Why not higher: Base rate is very low for qualified hitters; regression to the mean intensifies as PA accumulate through June. Why not lower: It’s not impossible. In 2023 Arraez hovered around .400 into late June; a single 4-for-5 or 4-for-4 on June 30 can place someone at .400 on July 1. Additionally, the resolution language could be interpreted to include non-qualified players on ESPN’s stats page. If non-qualified count, the chance that some player with limited PAs sits at .400+ on that day is much higher. Updating factors: - Up if by mid-June at least one qualified hitter is ≥ .395 (especially ≥ .400) with substantial PAs; also up if clarification indicates non-qualified players count on the ESPN page. - Down if by mid-June all leaders are ≤ .380. - Clarification swing: if explicitly “qualified hitters only,” I’d be around 7–10%; if “any player (all batters),” I’d be around 85–95%. Research assistant: No additional information provided; forecast relies on base rates, typical mid-season regression, and definitional uncertainty about ESPN page filtering.
